question.text: If \(x=\frac{1-t^{2}}{1+t^{2}}\) and \(y=\frac{2 t}{1+t^{2}}\), then \(\frac{d y}{d x}\) is equal to

solution.text:
\(\because x=\frac{1-t^{2}}{1+t^{2}}\) and \(y=\frac{2 t}{1+t^{2}}\)
Put \(t=\tan \theta\) in both the equations,
we get \(x=\frac{1-\tan ^{2} \theta}{1+\tan ^{2} \theta}=\cos 2 \theta\)
and \(y=\frac{2 \tan \theta}{1+\tan ^{2} \theta}=\sin 2 \theta\)...(ii)
On differentiating both the eqs.(i) and (ii), we get \(\frac{d x}{d \theta}=-2 \sin 2 \theta\) and \(\frac{d y}{d \theta}=2 \cos 2 \theta\)
Therefore, \(\frac{d y}{d x}=\frac{\frac{d y}{d \theta}}{\frac{d x}{d \theta}}=-\frac{\cos 2 \theta}{\sin 2 \theta}=-\frac{x}{y}\)

question.text: If \(\log _{10}\left(\frac{x^{3}-y^{3}}{x^{3}+y^{3}}\right)=2\), then \(\frac{d y}{d x}=\)

solution.text:
Given, \(\log _{10}\left(\frac{x^{3}-y^{3}}{x^{3}+y^{3}}\right)=2\)
\(\Rightarrow\left(\frac{x^{3}-y^{3}}{x^{3}+y^{3}}\right)=(10)^{2}=100\)
Applying componendo and dividendo, we get, \(\frac{x^{3}}{y^{3}}=-\frac{101}{99} \Rightarrow \frac{x}{y}=\left(-\frac{101}{99}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}} \ldots \ldots\) (i)
Hence, \(y=\left(-\frac{99}{101}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}} x\)
Differentiating, we get,
\(\frac{d y}{d x}=\left(-\frac{99}{101}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}}=\frac{y}{x}\) (from (i))

question.text: If \(y=a \cos (\log x)+b \sin (\log x)\), where \(a \& b\) are parameters, then \(x^{2} y^{\prime \prime}+x y^{\prime}\) is equal to

solution.text:
\(y=a \cos (\log x)+b \sin (\log x)\) On differentiating w.r.t. \(x\), we get \(y^{\prime}=\frac{-a \sin (\log x)}{x}+\frac{b \cos (\log x)}{x}\) \(\Rightarrow x y^{\prime}=-a \sin (\log x)+b \cos (\log x)\)
Again, on differentiating w.r.t. \(x\), we get
\(\begin{array}{l}
x y^{\prime \prime}+y^{\prime}=-a \cos (\log x) \frac{1}{x}-b \sin (\log x) \frac{1}{x} \\
\Rightarrow x^{2} y^{\prime \prime}+y^{\prime} x=-[a \cos (\log x)+b \sin (\log x)] \\
\Rightarrow x^{2} y^{\prime \prime}+x y^{\prime}=-y
\end{array}\)

question.text: If \(\phi(x)=\log _{8} \log _{3} x\), then \(\phi^{\prime}(e)\) is equal to

solution.text:
We have,
\(\begin{array}{l}
\phi(x)=\log _{8} \log _{3} x=\log _{8}\left(\frac{\log x}{\log 3}\right) \\
=\log _{8}(\log x)-\log _{8}(\log 3) \\
=\frac{\log (\log x)}{\log 8}-\log _{8}(\log 3)
\end{array}\)
\(\phi^{\prime}(x)=\frac{1}{\log 8} \cdot \frac{1}{\log x} \cdot \frac{1}{x}-0\)
\(\therefore \phi^{\prime}(e)=\frac{1}{\log 8} \cdot \frac{1}{\log e} \cdot \frac{1}{e}=\frac{1}{e \log 8}\)

question.text: If \(y=\log _{10} x+\log _{x} 10+\log _{x} x+\log _{10} 10\), then \(\frac{d y}{d x}\) is equal to

solution.text:
\(y=\log _{10} x+\log _{x} 10+\log _{x} x+\log _{10} 10\)
\(=\log _{10} x+\frac{\log _{e} 10}{\log _{e} x}+1+1\)
\(\Rightarrow \frac{d y}{d x}=\frac{1}{x} \log _{10} e-\frac{\log _{e} 10}{x\left(\log _{e} x\right)^{2}}\)

question.text: If \(f: R \rightarrow R\) is a function defined as \(f\left(x^{3}\right)=x^{5}, \forall x \in R-\{0\}\) and \(f(x)\) is differentiable \(\forall x \in R\) then the value of \(\frac{1}{4} f^{\prime}(27)\) is equal to (here \(f^{\prime}\) represents the derivative of \(f\))

solution.text:
\(f\left(x^{3}\right)=x^{5}\)
On differentiating with respect to \(x\)
\(\begin{array}{l}
f^{\prime}\left(x^{3}\right) \cdot 3 x^{2}=5 \cdot x^{4} \\
f^{\prime}\left(x^{3}\right)=\frac{5}{3} x^{2}
\end{array}\)
Putting \(x=3\), we get,
\(f^{\prime}(27)=\frac{5}{3}(9)=15\)

question.text: If \(y=2+\sqrt{\sin x+2+\sqrt{\sin x+2+\sqrt{\sin x+\ldots \infty}}}\), then the value of \(\frac{d y}{d x}\) at \(x=0\) is

solution.text:
Given equation can be rewritten as
\(\begin{array}{l}
y=2+\sqrt{\sin x+y} \\
\Rightarrow(y-2)^{2}=\sin x+y \\
\Rightarrow y^{2}-4 y+4=\sin x+y \ldots(\mathrm{i})
\end{array}\)
Putting \(x=0\) in the equation (i), we get,
\(\begin{array}{l}
y^{2}-4 y+4=0+y \Rightarrow y^{2}-5 y+4=0 \\
\Rightarrow(y-1)(y-4)=0 \\
y=1 \text { or } y=4 \\
\because y > 2 \Rightarrow y=4
\end{array}\)
Now differentiating equation (i) with respect to \(x\), we get, \(\frac{d y}{d x}=\frac{\cos x}{2 y-5}\)
Putting \(x=0, y=4\)
\(\frac{d y}{d x}=\frac{\cos (0)}{2(4)-5}=\frac{1}{3}\)

question.text: If <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">cos</mi></mrow><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></math> and <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">sin</mi></mrow><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></math>, where <math><mi>t</mi></math> is a parameter, then <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>9</mn><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>d</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac></math> at <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mi>π</mi><mn>6</mn></mfrac></math> is equal to

solution.text:
dydx=dydtdxdt=5cost-3sint=-53cott

d2ydx2=-53⋅-cosec2t⋅dtdx=531sin2t1-3sint

=598

Hence, 9d2ydx2=40

question.text: If <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">y</mi><mo>=</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mo>…</mo><mo>.</mo><mo>∞</mo></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mfrac></math>,  then the  value of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfrac><mi>dy</mi><mi>dx</mi></mfrac></math> is:

solution.text: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">y</mi><mo>=</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">y</mi></mfrac><mspace linebreak="newline"></mspace><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">y</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mspace linebreak="newline"></mspace><mn>2</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">y</mi><mfrac><mi>dy</mi><mi>dx</mi></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">y</mi><mo>.</mo><mn>2</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi><mo>+</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mfrac><mi>dy</mi><mi>dx</mi></mfrac><mspace linebreak="newline"></mspace><mfrac><mi>dy</mi><mi>dx</mi></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>xy</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">y</mi><mo>-</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac><mspace linebreak="newline"></mspace></math>

question.text: If <math> <mi>f</mi><mfenced> <mi>x</mi> </mfenced><mo>=</mo><msup> <mfenced> <mrow> <mfrac> <mrow> <mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow> <mrow> <mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow> </mfrac> </mrow> </mfenced> <mrow> <mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow> </msup> </math>, then <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mi>f</mi><mo>'</mo></msup><mfenced><mn>0</mn></mfenced></math> is equal to

solution.text:
By taking logarithm on both sides, 
 logx = 1+x log2+x−log1+x 
On differentiating, we get, 

1fx·f'x=1+x2+x+log2+x−1+x1+x−log1+x

Now, put x=0

f'0=f01+log22−1=f0log2−12

=2log2−1∵f0=2

x3+y3=t+4t

x6+y6+2x3y3=t2+16t2+8

     ... [By squaring both the sides]

⇒t2+16t2+2x3y3=t2+16t2+8

⇒x3y3=4    ...i

Differentiating with respect to x we get

x33y2dydx+y3·3x2=0

⇒3x3y2dydx=-3x2y3

⇒x3y2dydx=-x2y3

⇒x4y2dydx=-x3y3

⇒x4y2dydx=-4  ...[From (i)]

question.text: Let <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mi>x</mi></mfenced></math> be a polynomial of degree <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>3</mn></math> such that <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>21</mn><mo>,</mo><msup><mi>f</mi><mo>'</mo></msup><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>30</mn><mo>,</mo><msup><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>'</mo><mo>'</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>22</mn></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>'</mo><mo>'</mo><mo>'</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>. Find the value of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mi>f</mi><mo>'</mo></msup><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></math>.

solution.text:
Let f(x)=a(x-3)3+b(x-3)2+c(x-3)+d

f(3)=21⇒d=21

f'(3)=30⇒c=30

f''(3)=22⇒b=11

f'''(3)=6⇒a=1

f(x)=(x-3)3+11(x-3)2+30(x-39) +21

⇒f'(x)=3(x-3)2+22(x-3)+30

⇒f'(2)=11

question.text: Find the value of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>(</mo><mi>f</mi><mi>g</mi><mi>h</mi><msup><mo>)</mo><mo>'</mo></msup><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></math>, if <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi></math>, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>g</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>h</mi></math> are differentiable functions with <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo></math> <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>g</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mi>h</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math> and the derivatives of their pair wise products at <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> are <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mfenced><mrow><mi>f</mi><mi>g</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo>'</mo></msup><mfenced><mn>0</mn></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><msup><mfenced><mrow><mi>g</mi><mi>h</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo>'</mo></msup><mfenced><mn>0</mn></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><mo> </mo><mtext>and </mtext><msup><mfenced><mrow><mi>h</mi><mi>f</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo>'</mo></msup><mfenced><mn>0</mn></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>.

solution.text:
y=fgh

dydx=f'gh+fg'h+fgh'

=122f'gh+2fg'h+2fgh'

=12hf'g+g'f+gf'h+fh'+fg'h+gh

=12h·fg'+g·fh'+f·gh'

fgh'(0)=12h0fg'0+g0fh'0+f0gh'0

= 1 2 3 × 6 + 2 × 5 + 1 × 4

= 1 2 1 8 + 1 0 + 4 = 3 2 2 = 1 6

question.text: Let <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mo>:</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">ℝ</mi><mo>→</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">ℝ</mi></math> satisfy <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi></msup><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mi>y</mi></mfenced><mo>+</mo><msup><mn>4</mn><mi>y</mi></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mi>x</mi></mfenced><mo>,</mo><mo>∀</mo><mi>x</mi></math>, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>y</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">ℝ</mi></math>. If <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mn>2</mn></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>, then <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>14</mn><mo>·</mo><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>f</mi><mo>'</mo></msup><mfenced><mn>4</mn></mfenced></mrow><mrow><msup><mi>f</mi><mo>'</mo></msup><mfenced><mn>2</mn></mfenced></mrow></mfrac></math> is equal to _____.

solution.text:
Given, fx+y=2xfy+4y(fx

Put y=2 we get,

fx+2=2x×3+16fx

f'x+2=16f'x+3×2xln2

Now put x=2 we get,

f'4=16f'2+12ln2     …i

Similarly, fy+2=4fy+3×4y

f'4=4f'y+3×4yln4

f'4=4f'2+96ln2     ⋯ii

solving eq. i and ii, we get

f'2=7ln2

from equation i, we get

f'4=124ln2

Now ⇒14×f'4f'2

14×124ln27ln2=248

question.text: Find the value of  <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mi>f</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>g</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></math>, if <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mi>f</mi><mo>'</mo></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mi>g</mi><mo>'</mo></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></math> for all <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>f</mi><mo>'</mo></msup><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></math>.

solution.text:
f2(4)+g2(4)=?
ddxf2(x)+g2(x)=2f(x)f'(x)+2g(x)g'(x)

=2 f(x) g(x)+2 g(x)(-f(x))
=0

∴f2(x)+g2(x)= constant
∴f2(4)+g2(4)=f2(2)+g2(2)

=42+f'(2)2
=42+42=32

question.text: If for \(x \in(0,1 / 4)\), derivative of \(\tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{6 x \sqrt{x}}{1-9 x^{3}}\right)\) is \(\sqrt{x} \cdot g(x)\) then \(g(x)\) is equal to.

solution.text:
\(y=\tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{6 x \sqrt{x}}{1-9 x}\right)\)
\(=\tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{2\left(3 x^{\frac{3}{2}}\right)}{1-\left(3 x^{\frac{3}{2}}\right)^{2}}\right)=2 \tan ^{-1}\left(3 x^{\frac{3}{2}}\right)\)
\(\frac{d y}{d x}=\frac{2 \cdot\left(3 x^{\frac{1}{2}}\right)\left(\frac{3}{2}\right)}{1+9 x^{2}}=\frac{9}{1+9 x^{2}} \sqrt{x}\)
\(\therefore \quad g(x)=\frac{9}{1+9 x^{3}}\)

question.text: If \(y=e^{n x}\), then \(\left(\frac{d^{2} y}{d x^{2}}\right) \frac{d^{2} x}{d y^{2}}\) is equal to

solution.text:
\(y=e^{n x} \Rightarrow \operatorname{In} y=n x\)
Now, \(\frac{d^{2} y}{d x^{2}}=n^{2} e^{n x}=n^{2} y\)
and \(\frac{d^{2} x}{d y^{2}}=\frac{1}{n y^{2}}\)
\(\therefore\left(\frac{d^{2} y}{d x^{2}}\right)\left(\frac{d^{2} x}{d y^{2}}\right)=\frac{n}{y}=-n e^{-n x}\)

question.text: Let \(\phi(x)\) be the inverse of the function \(f(x)\) and \(f^{\prime}(x)=\frac{1}{1+x^{5}}\), then \(\frac{d}{d x} \phi(x)\) is equal to

solution.text:
We have, \(\phi(x)=f^{-1}(x)\)
\(\Rightarrow x=f[\phi(x)]\)
On differentiating both sides w.r.t. \(x\), we get \(1=f^{\prime}[\phi(x)] \cdot \phi^{\prime}(x)\) \(\Rightarrow \phi^{\prime}(x)=\frac{1}{f^{\prime}[\phi(x)]} \cdots\) (i)
Since, \(f^{\prime}(x)=\frac{1}{1+x^{5}}\) (given)
\(f^{\prime}(\phi(x))=\frac{1}{1+[\phi(x)]^{5}}\)
From Equation (i),
\(\phi^{\prime}(x)=\frac{1}{f^{\prime}[\phi(x)]}=1+[\phi(x)]^{5}\)

question.text: If \(x^{m} y^{n}=(x+y)^{m+n}\), then \(\frac{d y}{d x}\) is

solution.text:
\(m \log x+n \log y=(m+n) \log (x+y)\)
\(\Rightarrow \frac{m}{x}+\frac{n}{y} \frac{d y}{d x}=\frac{m+n}{x+y}\left(1+\frac{d y}{d x}\right)\)
\(\Rightarrow\left(\frac{n}{y}-\frac{m+n}{x+y}\right) \frac{d y}{d x}=\frac{m+n}{x+y}-\frac{m}{y}\)
\(\Rightarrow \frac{n x-m y}{y(x+y)} \frac{d y}{d x}=\frac{n x-m y}{(x+y) x}\)
\(\Rightarrow \frac{d y}{d x}=\frac{y}{x}\)

question.text: If \(f(x)=x^{3}+3 x+1\) and \(g(x)\) is the inverse function of \(f(x)\), then the value of \(g^{\prime}(5)\) is equal to

solution.text:
\(\because f(x), g(x)\) are inverse function of each other
\(\therefore g^{\prime}(f(x))=\frac{1}{f^{\prime}(x)}\)
Now put \(x=1 ; g^{\prime}(f(1))=\frac{1}{f^{\prime}(1)}\)
Hence, \(g^{\prime}(5)=\frac{1}{\left(3 x^{2}+3\right)_{x=1}}=\frac{1}{6}\)

question.text: Let \(f:(-1,1) \rightarrow \mathbf{R}\) be a differentiable function with \(f(0)=-1\) and \(f^{\prime}(0)=1\). Let \(g(x)=[f(2 f(x)+2)]^{2}\) Then \(g^{\prime}(0)=\)

\(f(x)\) and \(g(x)\) are two differential function on \([0,2]\) such that \(f^{\prime \prime}(x)-g^{\prime \prime}(x)=0, f^{\prime}(1)=2 g^{\prime}(1)=4, f(2)=3 g(2)=9\) then \(f(x)-g(x)\) at \(x=\frac{3}{2}\) is

solution.text:
\(f^{\prime \prime}(x)-g^{\prime \prime}(x)=0 \Rightarrow f^{\prime}(x)-g^{\prime}(x)=\) constant.
Putting \(x=1\), we get \(f^{\prime}(1)-g^{\prime}(1)=C \Rightarrow C=2 g^{\prime}(1)-g^{\prime}(1)\)
\(=g^{\prime}(1)=2\)
So \(f^{\prime}(x)-g^{\prime}(x)=2 \Rightarrow f(x)-g(x)=2 x+C^{\prime}\).
Putting \(x=2\) we have \(f(2)-g(2)=4+C \Rightarrow 4+\)
\(C^{\prime}=3 g(2)-g(2)=2 g(2)=6 \Rightarrow C^{\prime}=6-4=2\)
Hence \(f(x)-g(x)=2 x+2\). At \(x=\frac{3}{2}\)
\(f\left(\frac{3}{2}\right)-g\left(\frac{3}{2}\right)=2 \cdot \frac{3}{2}+2=5\)

question.text: Let \(y\) be an implicit function of \(x\) defined by \(x^{2 x}-2 x^{x} \cot y-1=0 .\) Then \(y^{\prime}(1)\) equals

solution.text:
Putting \(x=1\) in \(x^{2 x}-2 x^{x} \cot y-1=0\)
we get \(1-2 \cot y-1=0\)
\(\Rightarrow \cot y=0 \Rightarrow y=\pi / 2\)
Using the formula,
\(\frac{d}{d x}\left[f(x)^{g(x)}\right]=g(x) f(x)^{g(x)-1} f^{\prime}(x)+\left(g^{\prime}(x) \log\right.\)
\(f(x)) f(x)^{g(x)}\), we have
\(2 x \cdot x^{2 x-1}(1)+(2 \log x) x^{2 x}-2\left[x \cdot x^{x-1}(1)+(\log x)\right.\)
\(\left.x^{x}\right] \cot y+2 x^{x}\left(\operatorname{cosec}^{2} y\right) y^{\prime}(x)=0\)
Putting \(x=1, y=\pi / 2\), we get
\(\begin{array}{l}
2+0-2(1)(0)+2 \operatorname{cosec}^{2}(\pi / 2) y^{\prime}(1)=0 \\
\Rightarrow y^{\prime}(1)=-1
\end{array}\)

question.text: If <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>2</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><msup><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><msup><mi>cot</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><mfenced separators="|"><mfrac><mrow><msqrt><mn>3</mn></msqrt><mi>cos</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>sin</mi><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>cos</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><msqrt><mn>3</mn></msqrt><mi>sin</mi><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac></mfenced></mrow></mfenced><mn>2</mn></msup><mo> </mo><mo>∀</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>∈</mo><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mfrac><mi>π</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mrow></mfenced></math>, then <math><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac><mi> </mi></math>is equal to

solution.text:
2y=cot-13cosx+sinxcosx-3sinx2

=cot-13+tanx1-3tanx2

=cot-1tanπ3+x2

=cot-1cotπ2-π3+x 2

⇒2y=π6-x2, x∈0,π6π+π6-x2, x∈π6,π2

⇒ 2dydx=2π6-x.-1⇒dydx=x-π6, x∈0,π6

And dydx=x-7π6, x∈π6,π2
Left Hand and Right Hand Derivatives are not same so function is non derivable at x=π6.

Hence, dydx does not exist for all values in the given interval.

question.text: If y=y(x) is an implicit function of x such that loge(x+y)=4xy, then d2y dx2 at x=0 is equal to

solution.text:
Given:

loge(x+y)=4xy

When x=0, then y=1

logex+y=4xy

⇒x+y=e4xy

Now differentiate w.r.t. x

1+y'=e4xy4y+4xy'   …i

At (0,1)⇒y'(0)+1=4⇒y'(0)=3

Now, again differentiate equation (i), we get

y"=e4xy4y+4xy′2+e4xy4y'+4y'+4xy"

At 0,1

y"(0)=1(4×1+0)2+1(4×3+4×3+0)

⇒y"(0)=16+24=40

⇒y"(0)=40

question.text: Let, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mo>:</mo><mi>R</mi><mo>→</mo><mi>R</mi></math> be a function such that <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mi>x</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mi>f</mi><mo>'</mo><mfenced separators="|"><mn>1</mn></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mi>x</mi><mi>f</mi><mo>''</mo><mfenced separators="|"><mn>2</mn></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mi>f</mi><mo>'''</mo><mfenced separators="|"><mn>3</mn></mfenced><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mo>∀</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi>R</mi><mo>.</mo></math> Then <math><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfenced></math> equals

solution.text:
Let, fx=x3+ax2+bx+c

⇒f'x=3x2+2ax+b

⇒f''x=6x+2a

⇒f'''x=6

According to the question, 

a=f'1=3+2a+b⇒a+b=-3 ...i

b=f''2=12+2a⇒2a-b=-12 ...ii

c=f'''3⇒c=6

Solving equations i & ii, we get, a= -5 & b=2

⇒fx=x3-5x2+2x+6

∴ f2=8-20+4+6=-2.

question.text: Let \(f\) be a differentiable function such that \(8 f(x)+6 f\left(\frac{1}{x}\right)-x=5(x \neq 0)\) and \(y=x^{2} f(x)\), then \(\frac{d y}{d x}\) at \(x=-1\) is

solution.text:
\(8 f(x)+6 f\left(\frac{1}{x}\right)-x=5 \text { (i) }\)
Replace \(x\) by \(\frac{1}{x}\), we have \(8 f\left(\frac{1}{x}\right)+6 f(x)-\frac{1}{x}=5\) (ii)
Solving (i) and (ii) for \(f(x)\) and \(f(1 / x)\), we have
\(\begin{array}{l}
14 f(x)=5-\frac{3}{x}+4 x \\
\Rightarrow 14 f^{\prime}(x)=\frac{3}{x^{2}}+4
\end{array}\)
So \(f(-1)=\frac{1}{14}[5+3-4]=\frac{2}{7}\)
and \(f^{\prime}(-1)=\frac{1}{14}[3+4]=\frac{1}{2}\)
Differentiating \(y=x^{2} f(x)\), we have \(\frac{d y}{d x}=2 x f(x)+\)
\(x^{2} f^{\prime}(x)\)
\(\left.\Rightarrow \frac{d y}{d x}\right|_{x=1}=-2 f(-1)+f^{\prime}(-1)=-\frac{4}{7}+\frac{1}{2}=-\frac{1}{14}\)

question.text: For <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi><mo>></mo><mn>1</mn></math>, if <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>y</mi></mrow></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>y</mi></mrow></msup></math>, then <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>log</mi><mi>e</mi></msub><mo>⁡</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced><mn>2</mn></msup><mi> </mi><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac></math> is equal to

solution.text:
Given, 2x2y=4.e2x-2y

Taking natural logarithm on both sides, we get

2y loge2x= loge4+2x-2y

⇒2y=loge4+2x1+loge2x

Differentiating both sides with respect to x, we get

2dydx=1+loge2x.2-loge4+2x1x1+loge2x2 (Using quotient rule)

⇒1+loge2x2dydx=x.loge2x-loge2x.

question.text: Let <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mi>x</mi></mfenced></math> is an invertible function satisfying <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mn>1</mn></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><msup><mi>f</mi><mo>'</mo></msup><mfenced><mn>1</mn></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><msup><mi>f</mi><mo>"</mo></msup><mfenced><mn>1</mn></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>,</mo></math> then the absolute value of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>2</mn><mo>.</mo><msup><mfenced><msup><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></mfenced><mo>"</mo></msup><mfenced><mn>5</mn></mfenced></math> is equal to

solution.text:
let \(b^{-1}(x)=g(x)\)
\(g(b(x))=x\)
\(g^{\prime}(f(x)) b^{\prime}(x)=1\)
\(g^{\prime}(f(x))=\frac{1}{b^{\prime}}(x)\)
\(g^{\prime \prime}(f(x)) f^{\prime}(x)=\frac{-b^{\prime \prime}(x)}{\left(f^{\prime}(x)\right)^{2}}\)
If \(f(x)=5, x=1\)
\(\therefore g^{\prime \prime}(5)=-\frac{f^{\prime \prime}(1)}{\left(f^{\prime}(1)\right)^{3}}=\frac{-4}{8}=\frac{-1}{2}\)
\(\left|2 g^{\prime \prime}(5)\right|=1\)

question.text: If <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>y</mi><mfenced><mi>x</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><msup><mfenced><msup><mi>x</mi><mi>x</mi></msup></mfenced><mi>x</mi></msup><mo>,</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></math> then <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>d</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mn>20</mn></math> at <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math> is equal to

solution.text:
Given,

yx=xxx

Taking loge both side

lnyx=x2·lnx

Now differentiating both side w.r.t x we get,

1yx·y'x=x2x+2x·lnx

y'x=yxx+2x lnx .......(i)

Given y1=1, so y'1=1

Now rewriting equation (i) again we get,

dxdy=1xx2+11+2lnx

Now d2xdy2=ddxxx2+11+2lnx-1dxdy

⇒d2xdy2=-xx21+2lnxx2+3+2x2lnxxx21+2lnx3×1

⇒d2xdy2x=1=-4

So, d2xdy2x=1+20=-4+20=16
